[Pangalay](/wiki/Pangalay) - [Sagayan](/wiki/Sagayan) - [Singkil](/wiki/Singkil) - [Subli](/wiki/Subli) - [Tinikling](/wiki/Tinikling) Singapore - [Dikir Barat Singapura](/wiki/Dikir_Barat_Singapura) Thailand - [Lakhon Khon](/wiki/Khon) - Fon - Hun krabok - [Lakhon Nai](/wiki/Lakhon_nai) - [Lakhon Chatri](/wiki/Lakhon_chatri) - [Lakhon Nok](/wiki/Lakhon_nok) - [Likay](/wiki/Likay) - [Manora](/wiki/Menora_(dance)) - [Ma yong](/wiki/Mak_yong) - [Mor lam](/wiki/Mor_lam) - [Ram wong](/wiki/Romvong) - Ram Thai - Rabam - [Kingkara](/wiki/Peacock_dance) Vietnam - [Nhã nhạc](/wiki/Nh%C3%A3_nh%E1%BA%A1c) - v - t - e The **Branyo** is a form of [dance](/wiki/Dance) from Malaysia traditionally danced by the original Portuguese colonists of [Malacca](/wiki/Malacca) and their present-day descendants in Malaysia. It is a development of the Portuguese [folk dance](/wiki/Folk_dance) [corridinho](/wiki/Corridinho) from the [Algarve](/wiki/Algarve). Branyo has been an integral part of the Malaccan Portuguese festival of *Introdu* since the early 16th century. *Introdu* is known as Shrove Sunday or *[Quinquagesima](/wiki/Quinquagesima)* to the non-Portuguese speaking world and is the Sunday just before [Ash Wednesday](/wiki/Ash_Wednesday) which marks the season of [Lent](/wiki/Lent). This dance has enriched [Malay](/wiki/Malays_(ethnic_group)) culture and has influenced the later Malay dance known as the [Joget](/wiki/Joget). There are 4 rhythms in Branyo. They are *Jingli Nona*, *Canji Papa*, *Che Corte* and *Sarampeh*. - [Music of Malaysia](/wiki/Music_of_Malaysia) - Branyo Portuguese Dance Archived 29 September 2019 at the [Wayback Machine](/wiki/Wayback_Machine) - Gateway to Eurasian Culture This dance-related article is a stub.
